winners.tagline: Delivering warm beds to the homeless.

description_sections.heading: Link
description_sections.content: Visit 104.236.221.207 to view the project!

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: Our idea is inspired with the idea of making it possible for homeless people to easily find the nearest warm bed.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: Home Fly allows users to type in an address and it will return the list of nearest homeless shelters. We have a Twilio account set up to be able to text an address to our server and it will automatically return the nearest shelter's information.

description_sections.heading: How I built it
description_sections.content: We built it with the Meteor framework which allows us to utilize MongoDB for data storage. The rest was written in Javascript, HTML, and CSS.

description_sections.heading: Challenges I ran into
description_sections.content: One of the biggest challenges we ran into was efficiently managing our time. We had to cut out some great features that we would have loved to implement - we will be sure to add these over the course of time!

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: We're most proud of the fact that we have text message integration. Soon enough we would like every user to have the text message functionality!

description_sections.heading: What I learned
description_sections.content: We learned more about the Meteor framework.

description_sections.heading: What's next for Home Fly
description_sections.content: Coming soon...

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: css google-distance-matrix google-geocoding google-maps html5 javascript meteor.js twilio

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: We had an arduino, an led and a button and tried to think of what we could do to use all of it

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: takes morse code input on a button and navigates a binary tree to translate it to the english characters

description_sections.heading: How I built it
description_sections.content: with luck hope and love

description_sections.heading: Challenges I ran into
description_sections.content: binary tree navigation lcd screen malfunction i2c chip faulty wiring issues computer freezes com port failures spark core crossed wires no EE experience

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: binary tree navigation communicating with spark core communication over i2c timer logic dot-dash determination

description_sections.heading: What I learned
description_sections.content: spark core = bad binary tree implementation arduino supports only one comport voltage level switching with rx and tx

description_sections.heading: What's next for MorseToEnglish Table 7
description_sections.content: English to Morse over wireless

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: arduino c led

description_sections.heading: Inspiration:
description_sections.content: All of our team members have relatives who have dementia.

description_sections.heading: What it does:
description_sections.content: Checks if a patient has left a certain specified area (eg. their home) and gives an alert.

description_sections.heading: How I built it:
description_sections.content: Programmed in swift using xcode, use of geofencing and gps coordinates, and trulio.

description_sections.heading: Challenges I ran into:
description_sections.content: Started working in android but switched to IOS because we had issues with developer tools on our android devices and had more experience in xcode and swift. Trulio had poorly written reference material and libraries for swift 2.0.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: Figuring out geofencing and overlaying a shape on a map to show the boundaries. Overcoming the issues with trulio to eventually get text alerts after leaving the geofence.

description_sections.heading: What I learned:
description_sections.content: How to use xcode, android studio, swift, geofencing, and gps location, how to use trulio to send sms.

description_sections.heading: What's next for Wandr:
description_sections.content:
Option to call/text more than one family member, option to call emergency services with patient info and location, way to direct patient back home, a sister app to track patient from families phone.

Table #52

winners.tagline: Display homeless shelter information in your area realtime on any screen with internet access...

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: To help connect those seeking shelter, food, or general assistance to local organizations.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content:
Our app helps connect those seeking shelter, food, and/or assistance to organizations in the surrounding area. We do this by implementing an "easy to use" user interface that allows providers to create and broadcast up to date information including:

number of beds available within their organization fees age limitations gender specifications meal options contact info street address

This app is meant to be displayed similar to that of an airport arrival and departure board. We designed it to be broadcasted on screens at local community centers and homeless shelters around the country.

description_sections.heading: How I built it
description_sections.content: This app was built using Ruby on Rails

description_sections.heading: Challenges I ran into
description_sections.content: Working with relational databases and strong parameters Using git as a team - many times we had difficulty figuring out how to manage conflicts Visually manipulating pages using SCSS

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: The website looks pretty! We got a good grasp of how to style pages after 6 hours We're proud of the website concept. We believe this website would be of great value to DeKalb, Chicago, and the world! We both worked very well together using Rails (Bradley has never used the framework before) We ran into many mistakes and feel much more confident in navigating around those mistakes in the future

description_sections.heading: What I learned
description_sections.content: It's easy to assume a project will be easier than it really is. In reality though, we learned that we have to be realistic and allow for time to make errors or run into learning curve roadblocks We learned that it's very possible to quickly develop powerful web apps using the Rails framework. This is exciting! Again, we learned that mistakes may not be pleasant but are a very important part of the learning process

description_sections.heading: What's next for Shelterme
description_sections.content: We think Shelterme has tremendous opportunity now to provide a very valuable service to those in need. The development of this app will continue and we hope to be in the Chicago region very soon!

description_sections.heading: Name of Challenge
description_sections.content: *Shelter application

winners.tagline: Local events at your finger tips. Whether it's sports, concerts, or community gatherings, you'll always know watdo.

description_sections.heading: watdo
description_sections.content:
This project was made to address the difficulties in finding local community events offered through all nearby organizations. By pulling information from local Dekalb RSS feeds as well as the Eventiful API, watdo aggregates data in order to provide a streamlined user experience. Sort by type of organization, or simply scroll through the feed.

Before any day out, make sure you know watdo.

winners.tagline: Everyone says they have nothing to hide. But their Twitter accounts reveal otherwise.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: In the debate about privacy, everyone says they have nothing to hide, but few of us really do.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: This project mines the Twitter social graph to find evidence of politically subversive friends and followers.

description_sections.heading: What's next for Nothing to Hide
description_sections.content: We are collecting more data at the fastest speed allowed by Twitter. As our database grows, so will our ability to prove that everyone really does have something to hide.

winners.tagline: All ten evaluation guides for Toastmasters in one locations, with login capabilities to track evaluator.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: At the beginning of the Huskie Hack, our group was among the dozen or so hackers that did not have a group. Our group decided to work together on this problem, when on stage we decided it was something we all being new to the field might be able to do. With ages ranging from 13 to 27, we presented as a very diverse group with a lot of ideas and vision to offer to the project.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: We have digitized the hard copy versions of evaluation guides, providing the framework to develop a user-based system that will track user's submissions, storing the data they provide in a database that can later be retrieved in both digital and physical (through PDF printing) forms.

description_sections.heading: How I built it
description_sections.content: Using Meteor, the JavaScript app platform, we were able to create a template for each evaluation guide. While Joshua worked on the main functionality of the website, login capabilities, linking between templates, and coding, the remainder of the hackers wrote the templates, formatting them to look as similar as possible given the different ways in which data is collected on each form.

description_sections.heading: Challenges I ran into
description_sections.content: We first attempted to use Excel to create template .xls documents that would serve as the foundation for inputting and collecting data using available Microsoft web services. We ran into issues with the limited functionality of the online

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: Several of our members learned a lot about coding, especially in HTML, with some introduction to CSS and JavaScript, which was a wonderful experience for all involved (as stressful as it was during the last few hours.) We took five pages of paper and turned it into a fully interactive website.

description_sections.heading: What I learned
description_sections.content: When we started, no one in our group had experience using JavaScript, PHP, CSS, and a few of our hackers had minimal experience in HTML. One of our hackers, Joshua, had minimal experience using Meteor, but through vigorous searching was able to make the code functional and the web application look and function at a professional level.

description_sections.heading: What's next for Digitizing Toastmasters
description_sections.content: Data submitted on the interactive website will be retrievable for both display on the website and printing as a PDF in the format the evaluation guides are currently in. We were unable to make all of this functionality available due to time constraints and the limited knowledge of our hackers.

description_sections.heading: Built With
description_sections.content: css html5 javascript meteor.js

description_sections.heading: Try it out
description_sections.content: toast-masters.meteor.com

winners.tagline: A clean and simple visual representation of Illinois State census data.

description_sections.heading: Challenge - Community Statistics
description_sections.content: I would like to see either an app or a website that utilizes or displays census data in a unique or artful way. I've seen several impressive examples out there for other communities and would like to see the same in our northern Illinois region. Australia has created an app called Run That Town that utilizes this in a fun and enjoyable way. Closer to us, Chicago has a website called www.HeyJackAss.com that looks at crime statistics in the area. I think something like that here would be useful to bring awareness to the community.

description_sections.heading: Notes to reader:
description_sections.content: Displays population data of random related statistics Population data can be changed with another type of data The Information is on the entirety of Illinois ## Table Number: 58

description_sections.content: css html javascript muse mysql php

winners.project_title: Decide Whether Or Not To Look At An Eggplant
winners.tagline: You get to decide whether or not to look at an eggplant.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: Everyone is always told whether or not they get to look at an eggplant. Now the user gets to decide.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: A simple two-button system. Look at an eggplant or don't look at an eggplant.

description_sections.heading: How I built it
description_sections.content: HTML as a base, and some bootstrap to make it look real nice.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: Putting the power of looking at an eggplant in the user's hands.

description_sections.heading: What I learned
description_sections.content: This web application may give a user TOO much power.

description_sections.heading: What's next for Decide Whether Or Not To Look At An Eggplant
description_sections.content: Look at half of an eggplant.

winners.tagline: Interactive Anonymous Budget Modeling and Submission App for Dekalb City Council

description_sections.heading: Names
description_sections.content: Ziwei Ba, Kevin Renner, Larry Wang, Jonathan Hu

description_sections.heading: Team description
description_sections.content: We are not a high school team. We are students from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: This challenge appealed to us the most.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: Interactively shows the city budget and allows user input on it

description_sections.heading: How I built it
description_sections.content: We used Meteor, which is a framework built on top of Node.js and MongoDB for backend. For the charts we used charts.js, and we used a Java program to parse the JSON files.

description_sections.heading: Challenges I ran into
description_sections.content: We had issues integrating the javascript charts into the meteor webpages.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that I'm proud of
description_sections.content: We were able to accomplish all of our tasks-separately.

description_sections.heading: What I learned
description_sections.content: We learned a lot about Meteor and Javascript, and Kevin learned about Mongo as well. We got a lot out of this hackathon and we're proud of what we've done.

description_sections.heading: What's next for budget
description_sections.content: We hope to present a nice app!

description_sections.content: css html java javascript meteor.js mongodb
